repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Third Programmatic Financial and
            Public Sector Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Third Programmatic
            Financial and Public Sector Adjustment Loan (PFPSAL) Project
            for Turkey were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the
            risk to development outcome was moderate, Bank performance
            was satisfactory, and  Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the experience
            of PFPSAL provides a number of insights that speak to four
            distinct issues: (i) the critical role of country
            leadership; (ii) the importance of bundling knowledge and
            lending in Banks operations; (iii) the appropriate balance
            of the Bank's focus on supporting design and
            implementation of a program; and (iv) the specifics of
            programs in crisis situations. A High degree of up-front
            political leadership, ownership of the strategy, and the
            program by the key ministries in the government, and
            consensus behind the program were important preconditions
            for the successful adoption and implementation of reforms
            especially in the case of public sector reforms. The link
            between lack of public finance transparency and financial
            sector vulnerability was key for the success of the program.
            This underscores the usefulness of designing PFPSAL as a
            multi-sector program. At the same time, as the experience
            with the differing pace of implementation of the two
            components under PFPSAL III shows, separation into different
            programs may be called for at some point in time. In a
            much-improved environment waiting for an appropriate timing
            for the privatization of state banks has probably resulted
            in greater revenues than anticipated or that will have been
            achieved in faster sales. The increased interest in the
            Turkish banking sector was most unexpected only two or three
            years before partly because at the depth of the crisis it is
            easy to underestimate the extent of the recovery. Therefore,
            a broader conclusion could be that, On designing a program
            in the midst of a crisis, flexibility is particularly
            important regarding policy measures that may have widely
            differing outcomes under different states of the economy.

repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Second Programmatic Financial and
            Public Sector Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was modest,
            and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that The lesson
            learned indicated that a number of banks that had fallen
            below the minimum Capital Adequacy Ratio (CAR) level were
            re-capitalized from private sources. Vakif bank received a
            subordinated loan from the Savings Deposit Insurance Fund
            (SDIF) to meet the minimum CAR requirement. Presently only
            two banks remain with SDIF (Bayindir and Pamuk). Liquidation
            proceedings for Ticaret are continuing, although these have
            been interrupted from time to time by legal actions taken by
            the employee pension fund. Pamuk bank was re-offered for
            sale as of April 2003 and SDIF is currently evaluating the
            two active proposals. Bayindir's status as a bridge
            bank and the timing of its eventual liquidation will be
            reviewed at the appropriate time. The failure of Imar bank
            in mid-2003 was a serious blow. The bank, owned by the
            controversial Uzan Group, saw its license revoked by the
            Bank Regulation and Supervision Agency (BRSA) in July 2003.
            A subsequent investigation found that the bank: (i) vastly
            understated its deposits - a true total of US$5.5 billion in
            contrast to the balance sheet figure of US$550 million; (ii)
            had paid only a fraction of its with-holding tax
            obligations; and (iii) had sold some US$500 million in
            T-bills that it had never owned and was not licensed to
            sell. The Government announced a payment plan for individual
            depositors in November which will create a burden on the
            Treasury totaling some 2.2 percent of GNP. Imar bank has not
            been formally intervened by SDIF and therefore the blanket
            guarantee for depositors and creditors has not been invoked.
            Following completion of a review of the improvements
            required in the legal framework for bankruptcy and
            collateral foreclosure to facilitate resolution of
            non-performing loans (NPLs)-meeting a second tranche
            condition for Programmatif Financial Sector Adjustment Loan
            - PFPSAL II, a series of amendments to the Execution and
            Bankruptcy Act (EBA) were enacted in mid-2003. The
            Government has prepared a second set of amendments to
            introduce a pre-packaged bankruptcy option in the EBA and
            these additional amendments are expected to be enacted by
            early 2004.

repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Second Programmatic Financial and
            Public Sector Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Programmatic Financial and
            Public Sector Adjustment Loan Project aims at supporting
            reforms in the public sector, in response primarily to the
            financial crisis of February 2001, and, ensure as well
            continued social programs through adequate funding. To this
            end, the project will examine, and help the government amend
            as needed the banking regulatory framework, including
            strengthening of the new Bank Regulation and Supervision
            Agency (BRSA), and, restructuring/privatization of state
            banks. Regulation regarding banking failure resolution and
            problem banks, will be institutionally strengthened, through
            a process of aligning prudential banking systems, to reduce
            banking vulnerability, withstand external shocks (thereby
            reduce systemic failure risk), to position Turkey's
            banking sector for accession to the European Union (EU), in
            accordance with applicable EU banking sector directives.
            Furthermore, structural fiscal adjustment policies will be
            supported, to achieve macroeconomic stability, and ensure
            the protection of public social spending. The
            Government's public expenditure management reform
            program will be broadened, which includes improvements to
            budget planning, financial accountability, and public
            liability management, as well as initial steps for civil
            service reforms. However, the politically sensitive public
            sector reform agenda may be jeopardized by vested interest
            groups, while capacity constraints are also risks that may
            hinder the pace of envisaged reforms.

docna.cdata!:
Turkey - Second Programmatic Financial and
            Public Sector Adjustment Loan Project
